awd_titl_txt: Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decay with Germanium Detectors: Majorana Demonstrator and LEGEND
awd_abstract_narration:
The non-zero masses and neutral electric charge of neutrinos allows for the possibility that neutrinos are their own antiparticles (i.e. Majorana particles), in which case an ultra-rare form of nuclear decay known as neutrinoless double-beta decay (NLDBD) may occur.  If neutrinos are shown to be Majorana particles, it would provide an explanation for the very small masses of neutrinos; point to new physics at energies beyond the reach of our most powerful colliders; and motivate an explanation for the prevalence of matter over anti-matter in the Universe.   This award supports software and instrumentation research on an experiment to test the Majorana characteristics of neutrinos and the next phase experiment, called LEGEND.  Both experiments use ultra-pure germanium detectors and are at the cutting edge of science.  The PI will train graduate students in novel techniques that will allow them to compete in high-technology based careers.  Additionally, the PI has an innovative program in outreach to the public.  

The LEGEND Experiment will use the ultra-pure materials developed by the MAJORANA Collaboration and the liquid cryogen active shielding developed by the GERDA Collaboration in the construction of a phased-deployment ton-scale experiment with discovery potential for NLDBD at half-lives beyond 10e28 years.  This project will extend LEGEND's sensitivity to NLDBD and dark matter by building on a full understanding of the backgrounds in the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR and reducing backgrounds associated with cosmogenic Argon isotopes in a liquid cryogen compton veto.  Specifically, the PI and his group aim to: construct a comprehensive background model of the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR NLDBD experiment using Monte Carlo simulations and experimental data; investigate the feasibility of germanium detector array deployment in a liquid neon environment to extend the physics reach of LEGEND; and develop preliminary designs and background models for the LEGEND-200 (200-kg) and LEGEND-1000 (1000-kg) phases of the LEGEND experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported efforts to understand and mitigate backgrounds in two germanium-based neutrinoless double-beta decay experiments: The Majorana Demonstrator and LEGEND, through Monte Carlo simulation, background analysis, and development of mitigation methods.  Significant progress was made in all three facets for both projects, strengthening the capability of the LEGEND experiment to extend current sensitivities to the never-before-seen decay process by an addition factor of 100 beyond what has been demonstrated to date.

The Majorana Demonstrator concluded its search for neutrinoless double-beta decay in 2022.  Throughout its operation, background rates in the Demonstrator were higher than radioassays of construction materials would suggest, and determination of the source of the excess has been a focus of the Background Modeling Working Group, led by PI Green.  With the support of this award more sophisticated simulations were developed to provide higher-fidelity detector response to background sources in the areas of interest.  Further, simulations have been performed of a post-upgrade configuration of the Demonstrator, and ongoing comparisons of the pre- and post-upgrade configurations are under investigation.  At the conclusion of this award the development of a comprehensive background model supported by these efforts is ongoing, and is expected to be published in 2023.  This work broadly impacts the low-background rare-event search community, by providing information on acceptable materials and components, and identifying sources of background.  Beyond-the-standard model physics searches performed by the Majorana Collaboration have relied on the simulations and background modeling performed with the support of this award and have broad reach over fundamental physics.

During the award period, we generated a Monte Carlo background simulation framework, performed simulations, and based on those simulation results developed a comprehensive background model of the proposed next-generation germanium-based neutrinoless double-beta decay experiment, LEGEND-1000.  PI Green led the efforts of the LEGEND Collaboration in estimating backgrounds for LEGEND-1000, which were compiled in a pre-conceptual design report distributed to the community.  In July, 2021, the Department of Energy Office of Science organized a portfolio review of candidate next-generation experiments, in which LEGEND-1000 was selected as the preferred project, partially on the basis of the background model generated with the support of this award.

A potentially dominant background for both phases of the LEGEND experiment arises from the presence of the radioactive argon isotope 42Ar, produced in the atmosphere by cosmic ray interactions.  The beta-decays of 42Ar nuclei present in the liquid argon surrounding LEGEND’s germanium detectors can produce 42K ions, which can be transported by electric fields to detector surfaces where they subsequently beta decay.  In LEGEND-200 their impact is mitigated by surrounding detectors with nylon film to produce a physical barrier to the drift of potassium ions.  This method is insufficient, however, to meet the more stringent background goals of LEGEND-1000.  The baseline method of controlling this background in LEGEND-1000 is to use argon extracted from underground deposits, depleted in radioactive 42Ar.  To mitigate the risk associated with potential difficulties in obtaining underground Argon, we investigated the possibility of operating the style of germanium detector used in LEGEND in a liquid neon environment instead.  The lower boiling point of neon (27K) compared to argon (85K) would require p-type point-contact germanium detector operation in a much colder environment than previously demonstrated.  We showed that these detectors would still function at these colder temperatures, and that charge trapping effects that may spoil energy resolution can be mitigated.  While it is unlikely that LEGEND would need to transition to neon operation, this has extended our knowledge of charge trapping effects, and the cryostat we developed to investigate cold-temperature operation is being used to investigate detector response to 42Ar backgrounds in a subsequent award.
